pageContext.title: Grants, incubators, and more: Here’s how the Singapore government helps entrepreneurs
pageContext.content:
The Singapore government also provides many opportunities for entrepreneurs and startups in the form of grants and support programs. To obtain such assistance, applicants must present an original idea that can address a consumer need or demonstrate real benefits for a specific sector.

Photo credit: Pexels

It’s no secret that Singapore is one of the best places in Southeast Asia to start a company. It’s the only country in the region that has made it into the top 20 of the World Bank’s Ease of Doing Business Index. In fact, it came in second, next only to New Zealand. The closest ASEAN member country in the ranking was Malaysia, in 24th place.

Small wonder then that more than 35 percent of founders and investors in Southeast Asia named Singapore as their first choice for establishing a startup. They point to the city-state’s high quality of life, strong public infrastructure, access to capital resources, and ease of setting up a new business as key factors for their pick.

The Singapore government also provides many opportunities for entrepreneurs and startups in the form of grants and support programs. To obtain such assistance, applicants must present an original idea that can address a consumer need or demonstrate real benefits for a specific sector.

Below is a list of startup grants, incubators, and accelerators backed by the Singapore government.

Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC)

The Inland Revenue Authority’s PIC Scheme provides businesses with a tax deduction of up to 400 percent, as well as a 60 percent cash payout for expenses in six business activities:

  1. Acquisition and leasing of PIC automation and IT equipment
  2. Training of employees
  3. Acquisition and licensing of intellectual property rights
  4. Registration of patents, trademarks, designs, and plant varieties
  5. Research and development activities
  6. Design projects approved by the DesignSingapore Council

However, the PIC Scheme will expire after the current year of assessment. That period covers expenses incurred from January 2017 to December 2017. For registered businesses, the deadline for e-filing a cash payout application under the PIC Scheme is on December 15. Paper filings ended on November 30.

Productivity Solutions Grant

Seen as a replacement to the PIC, the PSG shoulders up to 70 percent of costs of purchasing or leasing IT solutions and equipment. Depending on the sector where you operate, these systems may include management of accounts, fleets, human resources, inventory, sales, customer relationships, and more.

To be eligible for the grant, companies must be registered and operating in Singapore, use the purchased or leased IT solutions or equipment in the country, and have at least 30 percent local shareholding.

Applications may be submitted on the Business Grant Portal.

Startup SG

Led by the Standards, Productivity, and Innovation Board (SPRING), Startup SG provides support to startups, accelerators, and incubators. It has a variety of programs for different groups:

  1. Startup SG Founder – designed for first-time entrepreneurs
  2. Startup SG Tech – aimed at tech startups in advanced manufacturing or robotics, biomedical sciences and healthcare, clean technology, information and communications technologies, precision engineering, transport engineering or engineering services, and food science and technology
  3. Startup SG Equity – co-invests in eligible startups with third-party investors
  4. Startup SG Accelerator – supports incubators and accelerators
  5. Startup SG Talent – helps startups attract global talent
  6. Startup SG Infrastructure – provides startups with working spaces
  7. Startup SG Investor – assists individuals and companies that invest in Singapore startups to access tax incentives
  8. Startup SG Loan – enables access to government-backed loans

The most relevant program for newbies is Startup SG Founder, which provides mentorship and startup capital. For every dollar the entrepreneur raises, Startup Founder SG will match it with S$3 (US$2.19), with a maximum allowable grant of S$30,000 (US$21,900).

To qualify, founders must apply through an Accredited Mentor Partner, such as Spaze Ventures, Velocity Accelerator, SMU Business Innovations Generator, or NUS Enterprise.

Founders must also commit to work on the company full time and not have any other type of employment once they accept the grant. They must hold at least 30 percent equity in the underlying company, which must have at least 51 percent local shareholding. To get started, applicants can download the form here.

Some startups funded: Cudy (edtech), Vouch (insurtech), Luminaire AI (advertising analytics)

Early Stage Venture Fund (ESVF)

Through its ESVF program, the National Research Foundation (NRF) seeds selected venture capital funds to bankroll startups. The NRF invests up to S$10 million (US$7.3 million) on a matching basis. The VC may buy out the NRF’s share within five years, provided that it pays back the seeded amount plus interest.

Some startups funded: NinjaVan (logistics), Aslan Pharmaceuticals (biotech), YFind Technologies (positioning systems – later acquired by Ruckus Wireless).

Seeds Capital

The investment arm of Enterprise Singapore, Seeds Capital currently works with more than 500 “deep-tech” startups. It focuses on three sectors: advanced manufacturing and engineering, health and biomedical sciences, and urban sustainability and solutions. It also works with over 40 incubators, accelerators, and VCs.

Deep-tech startups can receive up to S$4 million (US$2.92 million) in investment. Seeds Capital matches investors on a seven-to-three basis for the first round of S$500,000 (US$365,000) and one-to-one for the next round, which is up to S$4 million.

To be eligible, startups must be based in Singapore and carry out their core activities in the country. They should be able to prove innovative and intellectual content for their products and services, as well as scalability and global high-growth opportunities. They need to submit an executive summary and a business plan.

Some startups funded: Kaha (IoT consumer electronics), SmartKarma (financial research), myDoc (healthcare tech)

SG:D Spark

Through its SG:D Spark scheme, the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) helps startups in information and communications technology (ICT) and media. Companies enrolled in the program will have their grant applications prioritized by IMDA, and will receive help in recruiting talent.

Best of all, certain tech companies in the program will be given access to government demand, enabling them to build a pipeline of customers.

Applicants must have an annual sales turnover of less than S$20 million (US$14.6 million) and must be able to demonstrate how their product or service is different from competitors. Their guidelines as well as terms and conditions are available online.

Some startups accepted: Evvo (media and ICT), Impress (recruitment chatbots), Hyper Anna (data analytics)

Technology Enterprise Commercialization Scheme (TECS)

TECS assists tech startups in licensing intellectual property and creating adaptable business plans.

TECS assesses proofs of concept based on technical feasibility and commercial potential. Ideas in the prototyping stage are also welcome, as long as the applicant is deemed capable of carrying the project through to launching and business operations. They must also show proof of interest from either a customer or a third-party investor.

Qualified applicants with proofs of concept will receive up to 100 percent of cash for expenses, with an upper limit of S$250,000 (US$182,000). For those seeking funds for further research and prototype development, TECS can shoulder up to 85 percent of qualifying costs, with a maximum of S$500,000.

Some startups funded: D-Simlab Technologies (aviation), ViSenze (AI), Cyrus Innovations (security solutions)

Enterprise Development Grant (EDG)

A financial assistance grant, EDG focuses on 10 aspects, such as training, consultation, and funding for equipment upgrades. Supported by Enterprise Singapore and SPRING, it’s divided into three stages:

  • Core Capabilities
  • Innovation and Productivity
  • Market Access

A startup can apply for EDG as long as it’s registered and fully operating in Singapore, has 30 percent local shareholding, and is financially capable of finishing the entire project.

Applicants must prepare a proposal for new projects that are not yet generating revenue. They also need to submit an audited financial statement, proof of quotation for project costs, and other items listed on the EDG application checklist.

Some startups funded: Shopmatic (ecommerce), Anchanto (logistics), Igloohome (security solutions)

Business Improvement Fund (BIF)

Administered by the Singapore Tourism Board and EDG, BIF covers 70 percent of qualifying costs for tech startups in the tourism industry. This includes costs for maintenance, training, and equipment expenses.

To get in, startups must pitch an idea for boosting tourism, along with a comprehensive project proposal and quotations. The complete eligibility criteria and application form are accessible online.

Some startups funded: Aonia Group (training programs), Dynasty Travel (tours), Quotient Travel Planner (travel agency)
